flexibleText:
Adapted from web.dev, by Google, their actionable guidance and analysis helps developers learn and apply the web's modern capabilities to your own sites and apps.

In addition to this checklist on the topic of performance, the web.dev resources also help you learn about:

  1. Network resilience
  2. Security
  3. Search and being easily discoverable
  4. Enabling installation (i.e. PWA)
  5. Accessibility

This checklist is part of a comprehensive series on critical checklists for web development.

checklistItems.label: Measure your site's performance
checklistItems.flexibleText:
1. With Lighthouse
  2. With web.dev online

checklistItems.label: Compress images
checklistItems.flexibleText: Uncompressed images bloat your pages with unnecessary bytes. Use Imagemin to compress images.

checklistItems.label: Use video instead of animated GIFs
checklistItems.flexibleText: Animated GIFs can be downright huge. Replace animated GIFs with video for faster page loads.

checklistItems.label: Lazy load images
checklistItems.flexibleText: Lazy loading is the strategy of loading resources as they are needed, rather than in advance. Images that are offscreen during the initial pageload are ideal candidates for this technique. Lazysizes makes this a very simple strategy to implement.

checklistItems.label: Serve responsive images
checklistItems.flexibleText: Serving desktop-sized images to mobile devices can use 2â€“4x more data than needed. Instead of a "one-size-fits-all" approach to images, serve different image sizes to different devices.

checklistItems.label: Serve images with correct dimensions
checklistItems.flexibleText: Image sizing can be deceptively complicated. There are two approaches: the "good" and the "better."

checklistItems.label: Use WebP images
checklistItems.flexibleText: WebP images are smaller than their JPEG and PNG counterparts - usually on the magnitude of a 25-35% reduction in filesize.

checklistItems.label: Apply instant loading with the PRPL pattern
checklistItems.flexibleText:
PRPL is an acronym that describes a pattern used to make web pages load and become interactive, faster:

  • Push (or preload) the most important resources.
  • Render the initial route as soon as possible.
  • Pre-cache remaining assets.
  • Lazy load other routes and non-critical assets.

checklistItems.label: Preload critical assets
checklistItems.flexibleText: Preload is a declarative fetch request that tells the browser to request an important resource as soon as possible.

checklistItems.label: Implement code-splitting
checklistItems.flexibleText: Instead of shipping all the JavaScript to your user as soon as the first page of your application is loaded, code-split your bundle into multiple "pieces" and only send what's necessary at the very beginning.

checklistItems.label: Remove unused code
checklistItems.flexibleText: We often include libraries we're not fully utilizing. To fix this issue, analyze your bundle to detect unused code. Then remove unused and unneeded libraries.

checklistItems.label: Minify and compress network payloads
checklistItems.flexibleText:
There are two useful techniques that can be used to improve the performance of your web page:

  • Minification
  • Data compression

Incorporating both of these techniques reduces payload sizes and in turn improves page load times.

checklistItems.label: Serve modern code to modern browsers
checklistItems.flexibleText: If you want to use new JavaScript language features, you need to transpile these features to backwards-compatible formats for browsers that do not yet support them. Babel is the most widely used tool to compile code that contains newer syntax into code that different browsers and environments (such as Node) can understand.

checklistItems.label: Avoid invisible text during font loading
checklistItems.flexibleText: Fonts are often large files that take awhile to load. To deal with this, some browsers hide text until the font loads (the "flash of invisible text"). If you're optimizing for performance, you'll want to avoid the "flash of invisible text" and show content to users immediately using a system font (the "flash of unstyled text").

checklistItems.label: Use the Chrome UX Report to look at performance in the field
checklistItems.flexibleText: The Chrome UX Report (informally known as CrUX) is a public dataset of real user experience data on millions of websites. Unlike lab data, CrUX data actually comes from opted-in users in the field. It measures metrics such as first contentful paint (FCP), DOM content loaded (DCL), and first input delay (FID).

checklistItems.label: Use the CrUX Dashboard on Data Studio
checklistItems.flexibleText: Data Studio is a powerful data visualization tool that enables you to build dashboards on top of big data sources, like the Chrome UX Report (CrUX).

checklistItems.label: Use the Chrome UX Report on PageSpeed Insights
checklistItems.flexibleText: PageSpeed Insights (PSI) is a tool for web developers to understand what a page's performance is and how to improve it. It uses Lighthouse to audit a given page and identify opportunities to improve performance. It also integrates with the Chrome UX Report (CrUX) to show how real users experience performance on the page and the origin in aggregate.

checklistItems.label: Use the Chrome UX Report on BigQuery
checklistItems.flexibleText: The raw data of the Chrome UX Report (CrUX) is available on BigQuery, a database on the Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Using BigQuery requires a GCP project and basic knowledge of SQL.

checklistItems.label: Performance budgets 101
checklistItems.flexibleText: As with most other thingsâ€”to reach a goal you have to define it clearly. Start the journey by setting a performance budget.

checklistItems.label: Your first performance budget
checklistItems.flexibleText: When you set a personal, business or family budget, you are setting a limit to your spending and making sure you stay within it. Performance budgets work in the same way, but for metrics that affect website performance.

checklistItems.label: Incorporate performance budgets into your build process
checklistItems.flexibleText: Once youâ€™ve defined a performance budget, itâ€™s time to set up the build process to keep track of it.

checklistItems.label: Use bundlesize with Travis CI
checklistItems.flexibleText: Using bundlesize with Travis CI lets you define performance budgets with minimal setup and enforce them as part of your development workflow.

checklistItems.label: Use Lighthouse Bot to set a performance budget
checklistItems.flexibleText: Make sure you stay fast by automating performance testing with Lighthouse Bot.
